title: About
text: Does more wins for a starting pitcher mean it is safe to assume they also have a low ERA?

title: ERA vs Wins Scatterplot
text:
When we think of pitchers in baseball, our minds correlate a good pitcher with a low ERA with wins. Wins is a weird stat in baseball. According to the rule book of Major League Baseball “a starting pitcher must pitch at least five innings (in a traditional game of nine innings or longer) to qualify for the win”. But there’s a catch “A pitcher receives a win when he is the pitcher of record when his team takes the lead for good”.
To put things in simpler terms, a starting pitcher can only get the win if they pitch at least 5 innings AND have offensive support with a lead when they exit the game… AND your team must hold on to the lead for the rest of the game once you exit.
So not only does a starting pitcher’s win statistic rely on his offense to first off score more runs than the other team while he’s pitching, the relief pitchers after him have to record a hold on the opposition.
Let’s look at Baseball’s finest from the 2024 season. And how their wins and ERA compare.

ggplot(top_era, aes(x = ERA, y = W)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7, color = "skyblue") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray39") +
  labs(
    title = "ERA vs Wins — Top 30 Pitchers (≥20 GS)",

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









Weird. Now what if we grouped pitchers by their ERA and found the median number of wins for each ERA group on a box plot? Is there a correlation? Does having a lower ERA mean you’ll actually get more wins for your team?


Code
# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)

# Read in the pitching data
pitching <- read_csv("pitching.csv")

# Filter to pitchers with at least 20 GS and select top 100 by lowest ERA
pitching_filtered <- pitching %>%
  filter(GS >= 20) %>%
  arrange(ERA) %>%
  slice_head(n = 100)

# Create ERA group categories and order them correctly
pitching_filtered <- pitching_filtered %>%
  mutate(
    ERA_Group = case_when(
      ERA <= 2.5 ~ "<= 2.5",
      ERA > 2.5 & ERA <= 3.0 ~ "2.51–3.00",
      ERA > 3.0 & ERA <= 3.5 ~ "3.01–3.50",
      ERA > 3.5 ~ "> 3.50",
      TRUE ~ NA_character_
    ),
    ERA_Group = factor(
      ERA_Group,
      levels = c("<= 2.5", "2.51–3.00", "3.01–3.50", "> 3.50")
    )
  ) %>%
  filter(!is.na(ERA_Group))

# Calculate median Wins per ERA group
era_medians <- pitching_filtered %>%
  group_by(ERA_Group) %>%
  summarise(median_wins = median(W, na.rm = TRUE))

# Create the boxplot
ggplot(pitching_filtered, aes(x = ERA_Group, y = W, fill = ERA_Group)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.6, outlier.color = "gray60") +
  geom_point(
    data = era_medians,
    aes(x = ERA_Group, y = median_wins),
    color = "red",
    size = 3
  ) +
  geom_text(
    data = era_medians,
    aes(x = ERA_Group, y = median_wins, label = round(median_wins, 1)),
    vjust = -1,
    color = "red",
    fontface = "bold"
  ) +
  labs(
    title = "Wins by ERA Group — Top 100 Pitchers (≥20 GS)",
    x = "ERA Range",
    y = "Wins",
    caption = "Red points indicate median Wins per ERA group"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(legend.position = "none")





Median Wins Based on ERA




Okay, maybe they do correlate. But what about the BIG dogs? Like, the Cy Young finalists. Did their wins align with their ERA? Or was there some misfortune?


Code
# Load required packages
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)

# Read the pitching data
pitching <- read_csv("pitching.csv")

# Filter for pitchers with at least 20 GS and get top 10 by ERA
top10_pitchers <- pitching %>%
  filter(!is.na(ERA), !is.na(W), GS >= 20) %>%
  arrange(ERA) %>%
  slice_head(n = 10)

# Reshape data for slope chart
slope_data <- top10_pitchers %>%
  select(Player, ERA, W) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(ERA, W), names_to = "Metric", values_to = "Value")

# Create a label column that combines player name + ERA
slope_data <- slope_data %>%
  left_join(top10_pitchers %>% select(Player, ERA), by = "Player") %>%
  mutate(label_text = paste0(Player, " (ERA: ", round(ERA, 2), ")"))

# Create slope chart
ggplot(slope_data, aes(x = Metric, y = Value, group = Player, color = Player)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.2, alpha = 0.7) +
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  
  # Label with Player name + ERA on the Wins side
  geom_text_repel(
    data = slope_data %>% filter(Metric == "W"),
    aes(label = label_text),
    hjust = -0.2,
    size = 3.5,
    show.legend = FALSE
  ) +
  
  scale_x_discrete(position = "bottom") +
  labs(
    title = "Comparing ERA and Wins for the 10 Best Pitchers (≥20 GS)",
    subtitle = "Each line represents one pitcher — ERA on the left, Wins on the right",
    x = "",
    y = "Value",
    caption = "Player label includes ERA value"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "none",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    axis.text.x = element_text(face = "bold")
  ) +
  xlim("ERA", "W")





Slope Chart Comparing ERA and Wins for Top 10 Pitchers (≥20 GS) — ERA Value Shown in Label




This may be my favorite plot. I think as a pitcher myself, it’s interesting to see who’s making their ERA stand up and getting wins for their team, and who’s maybe seen some misfortune, regardless of individual triumph. Like my guy Paul.
